Note.text: If you'd like specialized in-person help, San Mateo County offers in-person help for restraining orders Mondays from 8am to 12 noon and 1:30 to 3pm at the Self-Help office on the 6th floor

DV0.text: What do you need help with?

DV1.text: Ask for a new restraining order

DVCheck1.text: Do you want protection from someone who has abused you or your children? (Abuse can be physical, emotional, financial, or take place online)

DVCheck2.text: Are they someone you: dated, married, or had an intimate relationship with, or are related to (parent, child, sibling, grandparent — by birth or marriage?

DVStart.text: You may qualify for a Domestic Violence Restraining Order

DVTiming.text: Note: If you file for a Domestic Violence Restraining Order before noon, you should get a response from the court that same day.

DVMinor.text: If you're under 12, a trusted adult must help you file. Please contact the Self-Help Center in-person or online via LiveChat for assistance.

DVAlt.text: You may qualify for a different restraining order: Civil Harassment, Elder Abuse, Workplace Violence

DVNotQual.text: A restraining order is only available if there has been abuse. You may want to speak to a legal aid provider about other options.

DVForms.text: To start a Domestic Violence Restraining Order (DVRO), fill out required forms

DV100a.text: Step 1: Fill out DV-100 (Request for Domestic Violence Restraining Order)

DV2.text: Respond to a restraining order someone else filed

DV3.text: Change or end an existing restraining order

DV5.text: Renew a restraining order before it expires

DVCQ.text: Have a question about filling out the DV100? View common questions here:

DVQ2.text: Is it free to file a DVRO?

DVQ3.text: Can I ask for a DVRO if I already have a criminal protective order?

DVQ4.text: How fast can I get protection?

DVQ5.text: Can I get a DVRO if I'm under 18?

DVQA.text: What if I don't remember the exact dates?

DVQA2.text: What if I need more space?

DV100f.text: If you don't remember the exact date, estimate and explain (e.g., 'Around August 2020')

DV100d.text: If you need more space, attach MC-025 (Attachment Form) or use blank paper

Proof1.text: If you have proof (texts, emails, photos), attach it to your request

DV100b.text: In DV-100, item 5: Describe the MOST recent abuse first — give specific facts

DV100c.text: Use item 6 and 7 to describe earlier abuse, including the worst incidents

CLETSa.text: Step 2: Fill out CLETS-001 (Confidential CLETS Information). Only the court and law enforcement see this. The other party does NOT get a copy.

DV109a.text: Step 3: Fill out DV-109 (Notice of Court Hearing). You only complete items 1 and 2 — the court fills out the rest

DV110a.text: Step 4: Fill out DV-110 (Temporary Restraining Order Request). You only complete items 1, 2, and 3 — the court fills out the rest.

DVReview.text: Once forms are filled out, go to the Courthouse clerk to file them and ask for a Temporary Restraining Order (TRO), or you may be able to e-file online at the court website

DVOptional.text: Do you also want to request other orders such as child custody or visitation, child support or spousal support?

DVPickup.text: Ask the clerk when your papers will be ready and how you'll be notified.

DVRead.text: When you get your forms back, read DV-109 (Notice of Court Hearing) and DV-110 (Temporary Restraining Order) carefully

DVCheckOrders.text: Was a Temporary Restraining Order (TRO) granted? Check if the judge signed DV-110

DVTROYes.text: You now have a Temporary Restraining Order. It lasts until your court date. Keep a copy of DV-110 with you at all times. You can also take photos of it on your phone

DVTRONo.text: A TRO was not granted, but you still have a court date where you can provide more information to support granting a restraining order

DVServePrep.text: You must now serve the other person with your court papers. Someone 18 or older (not you or someone protected by the order) must personally deliver the documents before your court date - the sheriff or someone else may be able to do this for you

ServeWho.text: Would you like the Sheriff to serve your papers for you? You must have the address or location of the other person.

SERStart.text: Step 1: Fill out form SER-001 (Request for Sheriff to Serve Court Papers)

AltStart.text: Step 1: Choose your server. The server must be 18 or older and not involved in your case. You cannot serve the papers yourself

SER1.text: Item 4: Location of the person to be served. List home and/or work address and the times they are likely to be at each location. If you have more than one address, you can list both in item 4a and 4b and include the hours they will be at each place

SER2.text: Item 5a: Type of court papers. Write 'Domestic Violence Restraining Order'

SER3.text: Item 5c: Court hearing date. Use the date listed in DV-109, item 3

SERSoon.text: Contact the sheriff's office as soon as possible via email, phone or in-person services. It may take them several days to attempt service

SERGather.text: Step 2: Gather your court papers to give to the sheriff

SERPacket.text: You will need: Completed SER-001, DV-100, DV-109, DV-110 if granted, blank DV-120 and DV-250, and any other forms listed on page 2 of DV-109 such as DV-105, DV-140, DV-108

SERDeliver.text: Step 3: Deliver your forms to the sheriff in person or via email or fax. Contact your local sheriff's office for instructions

SERConfirm.text: Step 4: Confirm with the sheriff that they received all forms and know your deadline for service

SheriffReturn.text: Did you receive a Proof of Service form from the sheriffs?

SheriffServed.text: If the sheriff successfully served the other side, they will give you a completed Proof of Service form. This tells the court that the other person was officially served and allows the case to move forward

SheriffFailed.text: If the sheriff was not able to serve, they will give you a form showing when and how they tried. This is sometimes called a Declaration of Due Diligence

SheriffCheck.text: If you do not get any paperwork back, contact the sheriff's office right away to ask if they served the other side by your deadline. If not, you may need to reschedule your court date

SheriffFiling.text: Make sure the original Proof of Service or Declaration of Due Diligence is filed with the court. If it has a court stamp in the upper right corner, it has already been filed by the Sheriff's office

SheriffCopy.text: Bring a copy of the form to your court date. If you were granted a Temporary Restraining Order (DV-110), and the other side was served, and its a CLETS restraining order, police can enforce the order if it is violated

AltSafety.text: If you think it may be dangerous for someone you know to serve papers, ask the sheriff instead

AltDeadline.text: Step 2: Check your service deadline. Look at DV-109, item 6 for how many days before the court date service must happen. Count backwards from the hearing date in item 3

AltPapers.text: Step 3: Give your server all court papers to deliver. This includes DV-100, DV-109, DV-110 if granted, blank DV-120, blank DV-250, and any other forms listed on page 2 of DV-109 such as DV-105 or DV-140

AltDV200.text: Step 4: Partially complete form DV-200 (Proof of Personal Service). Fill out items 1 through 3. Your server will fill out the rest after serving

AltServe.text: Step 5: Ask your server to deliver the papers as soon as possible and before the deadline. They must complete DV-200 and return it to you

AltRefuse.text: If the other side refuses to take the papers, your server can still leave them nearby and note that on DV-200

AltReturn.text: Step 6: Once you get the completed DV-200 back, make a copy of it for yourself

AltFile.text: Step 7: File the original DV-200 with the court. Bring the stamped copy to your court date and keep a copy with you at all times

AltTRO.text: If you were granted a Temporary Restraining Order (DV-110), the restrained person can be arrested if they violate it after being served if it's a CLETS restraining order

Attendhearing.text: Attend your hearing at the court on the day listed on item 3 on the DV109 you received. If you have evidence like pictures, text messages, or emails, you will need to print them out and make three copies of each piece of evidence. One copy is for you, one is for the judge, and one is for the other side. If you have witnesses who can help support your case, bring them with you to your court date.

DVA1.text: A DVRO can: Stop contact, harassment, or threats, require the person to stay away, make them move out, restrict firearm access, require support payments, create custody/visitation rules. It can also protect children, pets, and property. Police can enforce a CLETS restraining order.

DVA2.text: Yes. There is no court fee to ask for a DVRO. You also do not need a lawyer to file.

DVA3.text: Yes. A DVRO may still be helpful because: Criminal cases can be dismissed, and DVROs can include child custody, support, or family protection. You can have both at the same time.

DVA4.text: If you ask for a Temporary Restraining Order (TRO), the judge usually decides within 1 business day after you file.

DVA5.text: Yes, if you're 12 or older, you can file on your own. The court may ask for a trusted adult to help. If you're under 12, an adult must file for you.

DVA6.text: Abuse includes: Physical harm, threats, harassment, stalking, sexual assault, destroying property, or controlling your money or activities.

DVCustodyHelp.text: How will the court decide custody and parenting time? The judge looks at what is best for the child — safety is the top priority. You can describe the current arrangement and request specific time-share.

DVChildSupportInfo.text: If you would like to ask for child support, check number 24 on form DV100. Then fill out and file FL-150 (Income and Expense Declaration) with proof of income (like paystubs) from the past two months.

DVChildSupportExplain.text: How is child support calculated? The court looks at both parents' income and time spent with the child. Support usually goes to the parent who has the child most.

DVSpousalSupportForms.text: Check item 25 on DV-100, and complete FL-150 (Income & Expense Declaration) with proof of income (like paystubs) from the past two months. If you are also asking for child support, you only need to fill out the FL-150 once.

DVSpousalSupportExplain.text: How is spousal support calculated? The court looks at: The supported spouse's financial need and the other's ability to pay. Domestic violence can also be a factor.

RespStart.text: If you received any of the following forms: DV-109, DV-100, or DV-110, this means someone asked the court for a Domestic Violence Restraining Order against you

RespCheckForms.text: Step 1: Know what the forms mean. If a restraining order is granted, it could limit your contact with the person asking for a restraining order. If you and the other side have a child together, the restraining order can include orders for child support and custody. If you're married, it can include orders for spousal support, property control and/or restraint. A restraining order could impact your life in other ways, including preventing you from having guns and ammunition. You have a court date where a judge will decide if they will grant the restraining order, which can last up to 5 years.

RespCourtDate.text: Step 2: Review the forms. Check form DV-109, item 3. This tells you the date, time, and location of your court hearing. If you disagree with any part of the request, you must go to court

RespConsequence.text: If you do not attend your court date, the judge can grant a restraining order against you that could last up to 5 years

RespWhatAsked.text: Step 3: Read form DV-100 to see what the other side is asking for. Look at items 6 through 23

RespChildCustody.text: If you have children together, you may have also received forms DV-100 (which asks for custody or parenting time) or a DV-140 (which makes custody or parenting time orders).

RespTempOrder.text: Step 4: Read DV-110 carefully to see if the judge granted a Temporary Restraining Order

BranchTemp.text: Was a temporary restraining order granted?

RespFollowOrders.text: If you received a Temporary Restraining Order, you must follow all temporary orders. If you violate them, you could be arrested or charged with a crime

GunHave.text: Do you currently own or possess firearms, firearm parts, ammunition, or body armor?

GunDecision.text: You must turn them in, sell them, or store them with law enforcement or a licensed dealer within 24 hours of being served with the restraining order

GunWarning.text: Do not try to purchase or possess any firearms, ammunition, or body armor while the restraining order is in effect

GunOptions.text: You can turn them in to the police, sell them to a licensed dealer, store them with law enforcement or a licensed gun dealer, or transfer ammunition to a licensed ammunition vendor

GunParts.text: You must also turn in any firearm receivers or frames, including parts that could be used or easily turned into a receiver or frame

GunReceipt.text: Get a receipt (DV-800) from whoever takes your firearms and file it with the court within 48 hours

GunNo.text: Good. Do not try to purchase or possess any firearms, ammunition, or body armor while the restraining order is in effect

DVRStart.text: To renew a restraining order, you must file before it expires. You can file up to 3 months before the expiration date.

DVR710Start.text: Step 1: Fill out DV-700 (Request for Renewal of Domestic Violence Restraining Order)

DVRCLETS.text: Step 3: Fill out CLETS-001 (Confidential CLETS Information). Only law enforcement will see this

DVRFileHow.text: Step 4: File your forms with the court clerk and ask for a hearing date

DVRHearing.text: Step 5: Attend your hearing. Bring evidence of any violations or reasons why you still need protection

DVRSheriffCopy.text: Bring a copy to your hearing. If the order is renewed and CLETS-registered, police can enforce it

CHROStart.text: Civil Harassment Restraining Orders are for people who are NOT in a close relationship (like neighbors, coworkers, or strangers)

CHROFormList.text: You will need to complete these five forms: CH-100, CLETS-001, CH-109, CH-110, and CM-010

CLETS.text: CLETS-001: Confidential CLETS Information. This helps law enforcement. The other person will not see this form

edges.when: Ask for a new restraining order
Change or end an existing order
